newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish leftist party to censure government.
newsitem.headline: Turkish leftist party to censure government.

text.p: Turkey's biggest leftist party said on Tuesday it would file a censure motion against the Islamist-conservative government to preserve the secular democracy of the country.

"We decided it was necessary to start the legal process to free the country from this government," Bulent Ecevit, leader of the Democratic Left Party, told his MPs. He said the motion would focus on problems of the "secular, democratic republic, foreign affairs, economic and social issues and security."
Ecevit said the Islamist Welfare Party was the target of the censure and that many members of the junior conservative alliance partner would support the motion.
He did not say when his party would present the motion.
Necmettin Erbakan, Turkey's first Islamist prime minister, apparently renounced his radical pro-Islam and anti-Western election pledges when he came to power at the head of a coalition in June.
But he has angered the secularist wing of his coalition government and the powerful, secularist army in recent weeks with plans to build mosques and other Islamist programmes.
A new furore broke out at the weekend over an anti-Israel rally in Ankara's Welfare-held Sincan district, which was roundly condemned by secularist parties.
Twenty tanks and 15 armoured personnel carriers on Tuesday paraded through Sincan in an apparent show of strength by the army.
Military officials said the march was part of routine training exercises and denied any link to Friday's rally in Sincan.

The interior ministry has launched an investigation into Sincan Mayor Bekir Yildiz over the "Jerusalem Night" protest. His comments at the rally have been criticised in the media as a call for the implementation of the strict Islamic sharia law.
